title: People
text: This page will eventually feature our members!

title: Commitments: Now & Looking Forward
text: I want to create a space for researchers and applied practitioners to exchange ideas related to moral reasoning and development, engage in methodological creativity, and seek impact in their work. This requires heavy communication, relationship building, and openness to new ideas outside of our own disciplines and work. Ultimately, this would culminate in its own research society dedicated to the study of morality and moral development. The society would be comprised of a wide range of disciplines, with separate discipline branches as needed.

title: Commitments: Now & Looking Forward
text: I want to create a space for researchers and applied practitioners to exchange ideas related to moral reasoning and development, engage in methodological creativity, and seek impact in their work. This requires heavy communication, relationship building, and openness to new ideas outside of our own disciplines and work. Ultimately, this would culminate in its own research society dedicated to the study of morality and moral development. The society would be comprised of a wide range of disciplines, with separate discipline branches as needed.

title: Commitments: Now & Looking Forward
text:
Mission Statement
Current expectations are to first, build a small UCD community of graduate students who are interested in moral reasoning, fairness, justice, and other related concepts in their research. This would begin with an initial exchange of ideas (e.g., a reading group) and snowball into other activities such as community engagement, presentation of research, and collaboration. The more people the better, and so we want to set-up this reading group for long-term success in a sustainable way. Eventual governance positions will be set into place.

title: Commitments: Now & Looking Forward
text:
Commitment to Equity, Diversity, & Inclusion
Justice and fairness is inseparable from discussions surrounding morality, moral reasoning, and moral development. Any endeavor in creating an inclusive, interdisciplinary group dedicated to the study of morality, fairness, and justice must consider systemic racism and the oppression of systematically disadvantaged populations in our society.

üìë Discussion Guidelines

ParticipantDiscussion Lead



Being Open to Learning

What do you hope to learn from the discussion leader‚Äôs field?



Showing Up With Your Perspective

How can your expertise further inform, build on, or learn from the work presented today?



Sharing Resources

After reading the work, did it remind you of anything you‚Äôve read or seen previously? If so, please be prepared to share with the discussion leader and/or group.





Choosing a Paper
Below are a few guiding questions for choosing a work to share with the group.

What is a written work that ignited your passion for pursuing a graduate degree in your field?
What is a written work that is representative of your research interests?
What is a written work from your discipline that you think everyone should read?
What is a written work that either challenged your perspective or someone elses that you think everyone should read?



Crafting Discussion Questions

Do you want readers to be primed with any information or set with a certain mindset before reading the work?
What are the key takeaways you want readers to have after reading?
What excited you (or did not excite you) about this work? How can you communicate that to others?
How does your research expand the field, especially in light of the paper we read?



Logistics

Please share your a .pdf of your written work with the group. We will upload a copy into the relevant agenda page on the site and/or share in an email thread.
Please share any discussion questions too.
If there are any good summary quotes from the text, please share them too! We will add them to the agenda.
